ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The course was an introductory research seminar in hyperbolic geodesics and Teichmuller space.

I learned about surfaces, curves, and dynamics. Doing a presentation allowed me to become more knowledgeable about pseudo Anosov homeomorphisms. I also learned about the deep connections between hyperbolic geometry and free group theory.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course occasionally felt like it was alternating between dual purposes: an introductory course in these topics and a research seminar with the professors graduate students. This meant that the level of difficulty of the individual lectures varied a bit, with me as an undergraduate able to follow some much more easily than others. Caglar is a very good lecturer, with a very good understanding of the material and an organized, generally coherent presentation style. The graduate students presentations I generally found harder to follow than lectures by the professor.
The course was well taught and interesting.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course if you are interested in topology and geometry. You'll learn more if you do the readings outside of class, and if you have adequate preparation in hyperbolic geometry.
